| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | [monst.c#line469](/wiki/Monst.c#line469 "Monst.c") |

A **dwarf king**, h, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. A dwarf king is a [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid_\(monster_class\) "Humanoid (monster class)") monster that is the [strongest](/wiki/Strong "Strong") type of [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)"), possessing [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and the ability to [tunnel](/wiki/Tunnel "Tunnel") with a digging tool like other dwarves. A dwarf king has two weapon attacks.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Dwarf kings are now known as **dwarf rulers**, with "king" and "queen" being gendered titles.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [4.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.5 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [4.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated dwarf kings are always peaceful towards [dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") and [gnomish](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)") characters, and will mostly be peaceful towards other [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") characters. Dwarf kings do not appear in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") due to being lawful. A [dwarf lord](/wiki/Dwarf_lord "Dwarf lord") can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a dwarf king.

In addition to random generation, a dwarf king may appear as the random [h](/wiki/Humanoid_\(monster_class\) "Humanoid (monster class)") that is generated on level creation for each of the filler levels in the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines"). A dwarf king may also be one of the monsters generated in a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room") as the occupant of the [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne").

A dwarf king [can be generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") each of the following items:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- A 6⁄7 chance of a pair of [iron shoes](/wiki/Iron_shoes "Iron shoes") and an independent 6⁄7 chance of a [dwarvish cloak](/wiki/Dwarvish_cloak "Dwarvish cloak").

- A 1⁄4 chance of a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm"), combined with an equal probability of either of the following:

  - A [dwarvish mattock](/wiki/Dwarvish_mattock "Dwarvish mattock"), or
  - A [dwarvish roundshield](/wiki/Dwarvish_roundshield "Dwarvish roundshield") paired with either a [dwarvish spear](/wiki/Dwarvish_spear "Dwarvish spear") or an [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe"), with an equal probability for each weapon.
  - Dwarf kings that receive a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm also have a further 1⁄3 chance of receiving a [dwarvish mithril-coat](/wiki/Dwarvish_mithril-coat "Dwarvish mithril-coat").

- Dwarf kings that are not given a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm will instead receive either a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe") (1⁄3 chance) or a [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") (2⁄3 chance).

As [overlords](/wiki/Overlord "Overlord"), dwarf kings will always generate with armor of at least +0 and weapons (but *not* tools) that are at least +1.

## Strategy

Dwarf kings have two weapon attacks, which makes them quite deadly when wielding a dwarvish mattock, and they can have excellent [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") from their starting armor.

Since dwarf kings and [mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer") share the same glyph, you should use [far look](/wiki/Far_look "Far look") to correctly identify any h, especially at lower [dungeon levels](/wiki/Dungeon_level "Dungeon level"), or in the Gnomish Mines where the random h generated on level creation monster can be a mind flayer.

## History

The dwarf king first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

Some variants grant dwarf kings and other monsters AC bonuses for wearing [racial equipment](/wiki/Racial_equipment "Racial equipment"), and may additionally generate them with a [potion of booze](/wiki/Potion_of_booze "Potion of booze"). They may also make adjustments so that female counterparts to the dwarf king are properly named and generated.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the Gnomish Mines replaces dwarf kings with hostile [war orcs](/wiki/War_orc "War orc") at level creation with the exception of [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones"), so that player dwarves and gnomes will have to deal with hostile monsters like other races[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) - this does not occur in practice, since dwarf kings are never specified for generation when creating any of the Mines levels.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), dwarf kings are replaced by [racial monster](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") [kings and queens](/wiki/King_\(GruntHack\) "King (GruntHack)"), which dwarves are eligible to generate as.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), dwarf kings generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a 6⁄7 chance of being generated with a potion of booze.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), the [dwarf queen](/wiki/Dwarf_queen_\(dNetHack\) "Dwarf queen (dNetHack)") of dNetHack is a distinct monster from the dwarf king, rather than an otherwise-identical monster of a different gender - [dwarf clerics](/wiki/Dwarf_cleric "Dwarf cleric") will grow up into dwarf queens.

A dwarf king may appear as the ruler of a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room") - his court can contain dwarf lords, dwarf clerics, [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster\) "Dwarf (monster)"), [gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster\) "Gnome (monster)"), [gnome lords](/wiki/Gnome_lord "Gnome lord"), [gnome ladies](/wiki/Gnome_lady_\(dNetHack\) "Gnome lady (dNetHack)"), [gnomish wizards](/wiki/Gnomish_wizard "Gnomish wizard"), [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), and [leprechauns](/wiki/Leprechaun "Leprechaun").

Dwarf kings that are randomly generated outside of the Gnomish Mines are always generated with a potion of booze.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the monster is known as a **dwarf ruler**. Dwarf rulers that generate with [dwarvish ring mail](/wiki/Dwarvish_ring_mail "Dwarvish ring mail") have an increased chance of it being made of [mithril](/wiki/Mithril "Mithril"), which makes it behave similarly to the dwarvish mithril-coat of *NetHack*.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the monster is referred to as a **dwarf royal**, and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), the monster is also known as a dwarf royal as in EvilHack, and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor. Dwarf royals generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a 6⁄7 chance of being generated with a potion of booze, as in UnNetHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

Dwarfs have faces like men (ugly men, with wrinkled, leathery skins), but are generally either flat-footed, duck-footed, or have feet pointing backwards. They are of the earth, earthy, living in the darkest of caverns and venturing forth only with the cloaks by which they can make themselves invisible, and others disguised as toads. Miners often come across them, and sometimes establish reasonably close relations with them.... The miners of Cornwall were always delighted to hear a bucca busily mining away, for all dwarfs have an infallible nose for precious metals.  
Among other things, dwarfs are rightly valued for their skill as blacksmiths and jewellers: they made Odin his famous spear Gungnir, and Thor his hammer; for Freya they designed a magnificent necklace, and for Frey a golden boar. And in their spare time they are excellent bakers. Ironically, despite their odd feet, they are particularly fond of dancing. They can also see into the future, and consequently are excellent meteorologists. They can be free with presents to people they like, and a dwarvish gift is likely to turn to gold in the hand. But on the whole they are a snappish lot.

\[ The Immortals, by Derek and Julia Parker ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 367](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L367)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [sp\_lev.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 854](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/sp_lev.c#line854 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/sp lev.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Dwarf king

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
h dwarf king
Difficulty 8
Attacks Weapon 2d6, Weapon 2d6
h dwarf king
Difficulty 8
Attacks

Weapon 2d6, Weapon 2d6

Base level 6
Base experience 83
Speed 6
Base AC 10
Base MR 20
Alignment 6 (lawful)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 900
Nutritional value 300
Size Medium
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A dwarf king:

  • can tunnel through walls.
  • needs a pick-axe to tunnel through walls.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is a dwarf.
  • is an overlord to its kind.
  • is male.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • likes gems.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line469

A dwarf king, h, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. A dwarf king is a humanoid monster that is the strongest type of dwarf, possessing infravision and the ability to tunnel with a digging tool like other dwarves. A dwarf king has two weapon attacks.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Dwarf kings are now known as dwarf rulers, with "king" and "queen" being gendered titles.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 SLASH'EM
    • 4.2 GruntHack
    • 4.3 UnNetHack
    • 4.4 dNetHack
    • 4.5 xNetHack
    • 4.6 EvilHack
    • 4.7 Hack'EM
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Randomly-generated dwarf kings are always peaceful towards dwarven and gnomish characters, and will mostly be peaceful towards other lawful characters. Dwarf kings do not appear in Gehennom due to being lawful. A dwarf lord can grow up into a dwarf king.

In addition to random generation, a dwarf king may appear as the random h that is generated on level creation for each of the filler levels in the Gnomish Mines. A dwarf king may also be one of the monsters generated in a throne room as the occupant of the throne.

A dwarf king can be generated with each of the following items:[1]

  • A 6⁄7 chance of a pair of iron shoes and an independent 6⁄7 chance of a dwarvish cloak.
  • A 1⁄4 chance of a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm, combined with an equal probability of either of the following:
    • A dwarvish mattock, or
    • A dwarvish roundshield paired with either a dwarvish spear or an axe, with an equal probability for each weapon.
    • Dwarf kings that receive a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm also have a further 1⁄3 chance of receiving a dwarvish mithril-coat.
  • Dwarf kings that are not given a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm will instead receive either a pick-axe (1⁄3 chance) or a dagger (2⁄3 chance).

As overlords, dwarf kings will always generate with armor of at least +0 and weapons (but not tools) that are at least +1.

Strategy

Dwarf kings have two weapon attacks, which makes them quite deadly when wielding a dwarvish mattock, and they can have excellent AC from their starting armor.

Since dwarf kings and mind flayers share the same glyph, you should use far look to correctly identify any h, especially at lower dungeon levels, or in the Gnomish Mines where the random h generated on level creation monster can be a mind flayer.

History

The dwarf king first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Variants

Some variants grant dwarf kings and other monsters AC bonuses for wearing racial equipment, and may additionally generate them with a potion of booze. They may also make adjustments so that female counterparts to the dwarf king are properly named and generated.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the Gnomish Mines replaces dwarf kings with hostile war orcs at level creation with the exception of bones, so that player dwarves and gnomes will have to deal with hostile monsters like other races[2] - this does not occur in practice, since dwarf kings are never specified for generation when creating any of the Mines levels.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, dwarf kings are replaced by racial monster kings and queens, which dwarves are eligible to generate as.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, dwarf kings generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a 6⁄7 chance of being generated with a potion of booze.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, the dwarf queen of dNetHack is a distinct monster from the dwarf king, rather than an otherwise-identical monster of a different gender - dwarf clerics will grow up into dwarf queens.

A dwarf king may appear as the ruler of a throne room - his court can contain dwarf lords, dwarf clerics, dwarves, gnomes, gnome lords, gnome ladies, gnomish wizards, hobbits, and leprechauns.

Dwarf kings that are randomly generated outside of the Gnomish Mines are always generated with a potion of booze.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, the monster is known as a dwarf ruler. Dwarf rulers that generate with dwarvish ring mail have an increased chance of it being made of mithril, which makes it behave similarly to the dwarvish mithril-coat of NetHack.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, the monster is referred to as a dwarf royal, and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, the monster is also known as a dwarf royal as in EvilHack, and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor. Dwarf royals generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a 6⁄7 chance of being generated with a potion of booze, as in UnNetHack.

Encyclopedia entry

Dwarfs have faces like men (ugly men, with wrinkled, leathery skins), but are generally either flat-footed, duck-footed, or have feet pointing backwards. They are of the earth, earthy, living in the darkest of caverns and venturing forth only with the cloaks by which they can make themselves invisible, and others disguised as toads. Miners often come across them, and sometimes establish reasonably close relations with them.... The miners of Cornwall were always delighted to hear a bucca busily mining away, for all dwarfs have an infallible nose for precious metals.
Among other things, dwarfs are rightly valued for their skill as blacksmiths and jewellers: they made Odin his famous spear Gungnir, and Thor his hammer; for Freya they designed a magnificent necklace, and for Frey a golden boar. And in their spare time they are excellent bakers. Ironically, despite their odd feet, they are particularly fond of dancing. They can also see into the future, and consequently are excellent meteorologists. They can be free with presents to people they like, and a dwarvish gift is likely to turn to gold in the hand. But on the whole they are a snappish lot.

[ The Immortals, by Derek and Julia Parker ]

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 367
  2. ↑ sp_lev.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 854

A '''dwarf king''', {{monsym|dwarf king}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. A dwarf king is a [[Humanoid (monster class)|humanoid]] monster that is the [[strong]]est type of [[Dwarf (monster attribute)|dwarf]], possessing [[infravision]] and the ability to [[tunnel]] with a digging tool like other dwarves. A dwarf king has two weapon attacks.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Dwarf kings are now known as '''dwarf rulers''', with "king" and "queen" being gendered titles.}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated dwarf kings are always peaceful towards [[Dwarf (starting race)|dwarven]] and [[Gnome (starting race)|gnomish]] characters, and will mostly be peaceful towards other [[lawful]] characters. Dwarf kings do not appear in [[Gehennom]] due to being lawful. A [[dwarf lord]] can [[grow up]] into a dwarf king.

In addition to random generation, a dwarf king may appear as the random {{mcsl|h}} that is generated on level creation for each of the filler levels in the [[Gnomish Mines]]. A dwarf king may also be one of the monsters generated in a [[throne room]] as the occupant of the [[throne]].

A dwarf king [[Monster starting inventory|can be generated with]] each of the following items:{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|367|nethack=3.6.7}}

* A {{frac|6|7}} chance of a pair of [[iron shoes]] and an independent {{frac|6|7}} chance of a [[dwarvish cloak]].
* A {{frac|4}} chance of a [[dwarvish short sword]] and [[dwarvish iron helm]], combined with an equal probability of either of the following:
** A [[dwarvish mattock]], or
** A [[dwarvish roundshield]] paired with either a [[dwarvish spear]] or an [[axe]], with an equal probability for each weapon.
** Dwarf kings that receive a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm also have a further {{frac|3}} chance of receiving a [[dwarvish mithril-coat]].
* Dwarf kings that are not given a dwarvish short sword and dwarvish iron helm will instead receive either a [[pick-axe]] ({{frac|3}} chance) or a [[dagger]] ({{frac|2|3}} chance).

As [[overlord]]s, dwarf kings will always generate with armor of at least +0 and weapons (but ''not'' tools) that are at least +1.

==Strategy==
Dwarf kings have two weapon attacks, which makes them quite deadly when wielding a dwarvish mattock, and they can have excellent [[AC]] from their starting armor.

Since dwarf kings and [[mind flayer]]s share the same glyph, you should use [[far look]] to correctly identify any {{magenta|h}}, especially at lower [[dungeon level]]s, or in the Gnomish Mines where the random {{white|h}} generated on level creation monster can be a mind flayer.

==History==
The dwarf king first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Variants==
Some variants grant dwarf kings and other monsters AC bonuses for wearing [[racial equipment]], and may additionally generate them with a [[potion of booze]]. They may also make adjustments so that female counterparts to the dwarf king are properly named and generated.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], the Gnomish Mines replaces dwarf kings with hostile [[war orc]]s at level creation with the exception of [[bones]], so that player dwarves and gnomes will have to deal with hostile monsters like other races{{refsrc|sp_lev.c|854|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} - this does not occur in practice, since dwarf kings are never specified for generation when creating any of the Mines levels.

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], dwarf kings are replaced by [[racial monster]] [[King (GruntHack)|kings and queens]], which dwarves are eligible to generate as.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], dwarf kings generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a {{frac|6|7}} chance of being generated with a potion of booze.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], the [[Dwarf queen (dNetHack)|dwarf queen]] of dNetHack is a distinct monster from the dwarf king, rather than an otherwise-identical monster of a different gender - [[dwarf cleric]]s will grow up into dwarf queens.

A dwarf king may appear as the ruler of a [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]] - his court can contain dwarf lords, dwarf clerics, [[Dwarf (monster)|dwarves]], [[Gnome (monster)|gnomes]], [[gnome lord]]s, [[Gnome lady (dNetHack)|gnome ladies]], [[gnomish wizard]]s, [[hobbit]]s, and [[leprechaun]]s.

Dwarf kings that are randomly generated outside of the Gnomish Mines are always generated with a potion of booze.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], the monster is known as a '''dwarf ruler'''. Dwarf rulers that generate with [[dwarvish ring mail]] have an increased chance of it being made of [[mithril]], which makes it behave similarly to the dwarvish mithril-coat of ''NetHack''.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], the monster is referred to as a '''dwarf royal''', and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], the monster is also known as a dwarf royal as in EvilHack, and dwarf royals gain +1 bonus AC for each piece of worn dwarven armor. Dwarf royals generated outside of the Gnomish Mines have a {{frac|6|7}} chance of being generated with a potion of booze, as in UnNetHack.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
Dwarfs have faces like men (ugly men, with wrinkled, leathery skins), but are generally either flat-footed, duck-footed, or have feet pointing backwards.  They are of the earth, earthy, living in the darkest of caverns and venturing forth only with the cloaks by which they can make themselves invisible, and others disguised as toads.  Miners often come across them, and sometimes establish reasonably close relations with them.... The miners of Cornwall were always delighted to hear a bucca busily mining away, for all dwarfs have an infallible nose for precious metals.
Among other things, dwarfs are rightly valued for their skill as blacksmiths and jewellers: they made Odin his famous spear Gungnir, and Thor his hammer; for Freya they designed a magnificent necklace, and for Frey a golden boar.  And in their spare time they are excellent bakers.  Ironically, despite their odd feet, they are particularly fond of dancing.  They can also see into the future, and consequently are excellent meteorologists.  They can be free with presents to people they like, and a dwarvish gift is likely to turn to gold in the hand.  But on the whole they are a snappish lot.
|[ The Immortals, by Derek and Julia Parker ]
}}
